column81: While in principle the idea of reviewing code/data is great, in practice this places too much of a burden on the reviewer; given the diversity of software platforms and dependencies which may be present, it would be too easy for a trivial issue (eg: version difference in some dependent module) to derail the process. There is a tremendous gap between releasing basic, functioning code in the interests of openness and transparency, and releasing a complete, convenient package which may be trivially installed and run by any reviewer (or other) who may or may not have access to (or sufficient direct experience with) any necessary, related components.    Question four is perhaps poorly worded, since it discusses options which are not broadly available today. I'd absolutely like to see tracked updates and linked code/data, even if it doesn't affect publishing decisions so much at this stage...

column54: Current platforms (WholeTale, Code Ocean, Travis/Circle) can show me that the code can reproduce the results in many cases. In other cases (DataLad, blockchain implementations) can inform me that what the authors claimed is indeed correct through transactional recording.
column67: Consider institutional repositories to reduce dissemination costs, and hence make the costs of publishing transparent.
column80: Diversity can take many forms. Much as many academic committees involve people at different levels, gender, ethnic groups, and domain expertise, I would expect Aperture to support such diversity in every aspect, as practically feasible. For Aperture, it should also take into consideration geographic diversity.
column81: The concept of Aperture is great. In many other areas of neuroscience, society journals have become revenue streams that have compelled the society to not move away from a pay model (Science, J Neuro, AIP, IEEE). Given this journal is being started in the 21st century, and we already have examples like Wikipedia/Wikidata, every effort should be made to make information as accessible as possible worldwide without as limited an APC as possible. Many institutions are setting up their own repositories, and it would be worthwhile for the OHBM society to partner with such institutions. In cases of public/accessible data (FCP-Indi, ABCD, UK Biobank and others), I would request that OHBM/Aperture work with these sources to track components of data that are used in Aperture publications. Aperture has a chance to redefine culture in the neuroimaging community without changing the quality of publications. At the same time, I would encourage that Aperture develop clear principles to indicate that the submissions are not just end points of research threads, but contribute to entities (results, code, data, tutorials, opinions) that can be reused by others. It should also provide a way to indicate what contributions are being made by authors: https://elifesciences.org/labs/b86daa1d/author-contributions-recognising-researchers-for-the-work-they-do . Let's use Aperture to move away from an archaic information filtering system to one that truly enables growth of knowledge.    I would be happy to provide additional details as necessary.    Satrajit Ghosh

column67: How about a donation model, similar to the Guardian newspaper? No paywall, but also no mandatory publishing fees. Instead, we mention the actual costs (like Wikipedia does) of publishing and tell readers (and authors) how much an article read/publication would cost. They can then decide freely what to give and what suits their usage. This way we neither block readers nor authors from low-income countries to educate themselves or others. And I do think that most institutions who have the money would support this or we can promote this model to the general public.
column80: Make sure to include editors from low-income countries to have advocates against paywalls on either readers' or authors' side.    Make sure that reviews indeed become fair - the editors should be much more critical to unfair (misogynous, homophobic, (academic) age-discriminating) review(er)s. Publishing the reviews and linking them (even anonymously) to each other helps profiling bad reviewers, publishing editor notes puts more pressure on the editors to step in where necessary.
column81: Great initiative. What is really needed, however, is to give academic credit to the additional load that implementing these concepts (e.g., code review) will put on reviewers, editors. There should be a c(community-) or o(pen science) index for each researcher that reflects her/his/.../ engagement for such publication models beyond being an author with many papers.

column81: The results of this survey will NOT be valid in my opinion and should NOT be presented to the OHBM community as reflecting the desires of the OHBM community as a whole.      This survey approach is fundamentally flawed and as SCIENTISTS this should be understood.    This survey will likely be completed by those most interested in changing to a new open system and tearing down the current publication system.  The more militant the perspective the more likely they will be to complete this survey.    I'm sorry to say this but the results of this survey are obvious before a single person completes it.

column80: Have a code of conduct.  Try as much as possible to balance minorities within the editorial board (horizontally and vertically).   Try to include younger researchers too.  Try to have policies in place to incite turn-over: position (e.g EIC) can only be held for a certain duration and cannot be held two times in a row by same person.  Publish their stats about diversity: e.g https://biaswatchneuro.com/2018/11/23/october-2018-journal-watch/
column81: Explicitly support:  - direct (or less direct) replication studies  - offer registered reports format (level 3 TOP guidelines: https://cos.io/our-services/top-guidelines/)  - offer exploraotyr reports format (like Cortex does: https://www.elsevier.com/__data/promis_misc/Exploratory_Reports_Guidelines.pdf)  - implement the pottery barn rule: https://thehardestscience.com/2012/09/27/a-pottery-barn-rule-for-scientific-journals/  -

column81: I want to qualify my response to the issue of a publication specifically associated with and managed by OHBM:  If OHBM chose to create a publication for its membership, then it would need to be inclusive to standard empirical and review articles (which I had earlier indicated I did not favor as other publications fulfill this need).  If OHBM were to publish such a journal, then I would think it should both manage the publication and financially benefit from its growth.  In other words, I have two scenarios when this survey allows for only one.  I think the community as a whole would benefit from a NOVEL publication, one focused on data and code more than standard research articles and my responses reflect that preference.

column81: Reviewing code sounds like a good idea if you have never done something like that before. I've looked at lots of code written by others and, in my experience, scientists write shitty code. Not to say that it doesn't do what was intended. More that it can be very difficult to decipher how it works. I would enforce public release of the code and let the community review it.
